Arg.V:
#!/bin/bash
function updatepk() { if [ ! -z $1 ]; then if [ -e /var/run/yum.pid ];then exit 10 fi result=`yum -y update $1 2>&1` status=$? commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: command not found"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
commandexist=`echo $result | grep -E "yum: No such file or directory"` if [ "$commandexist" != "" ]; then exit 8 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "lock /var/run/yum.pid"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
islock=`echo $result | grep -E "/var/run/yum.pid: another copy is running"`
if [ "$islock" != "" ]; then exit 10 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "There was an error communicating with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "This system is not registered with RHN"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi
isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "No Repositories Available to Set Up"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isnotconnected=`echo $result | grep -E "Error Class Code: 9 Error Class Info: Invalid System Credentials"` if [ "$isnotconnected" != "" ]; then exit 9 fi isscriptletfailed=`echo $result | grep -E "error:" | grep -E "scriptlet failed, exit status 255"` if [ "$isscriptletfailed" != "" ]; then exit 6 fi if [ $status -ne 0 ];then exit 7 fi fi } updatepk nuxwdog
exit 0

exit 0

Vulnerability.Title: nuxwdog bug fix update
Vulnerability.Description: The nuxwdog packages provide a watchdog daemon that is used to start, stop, and monitor system processes, as well as to prompt users for passwords when required. Additionally, interfaces to the client code for various programming languages are included to allow clients to interact with the nuxwdog daemon. The nuxwdog packages have been updated to ensure correct operation on Power little endian architectures. (BZ#1229817) This update fixes the following bug: When using Red Hat Certificate System version 10, retrieving a stored password with the nuxwdog daemon previously caused the password not to be correctly null-terminated. This update fixes the underlying code, and the password is null-terminated as expected in the described scenario. In addition, it is now possible to use nuxwdog to prompt for passwords for programs or daemons started by the systemd service. (BZ#1214838) Users of nuxwdog are advised to upgrade to these updated packages, which fix this bug. Note for remediation: Please disable the SELinux for RHEL 4/5 when repairing, or some rpm packages will fail to install.
